subsection.title: Introduction
subsection.p: You know that not all quadratic equations have real solutions.

sidebyside.p: For example, the graph of f(x) = x^2 - 2x + 2 has no x-intercepts (as shown at right), and the equation x^2 - 2x + 2 = 0 has no real solutions.

subsection.p: We can still use completing the square or the quadratic formula to solve the equation.

subsection.title: Imaginary Numbers
subsection.p: Although square roots of negative numbers such as \sqrt{-4} are not real numbers, they occur often in mathematics and its applications.

Mathematicians began working with square roots of negative numbers in the sixteenth century, in their attempts to solve quadratic and cubic equations. Ren√© Descartes gave them the name imaginary numbers, which reflected the mistrust with which mathematicians regarded them at the time. Today, however, such numbers are well understood and used routinely by scientists and engineers.
We begin by defining a new number, i, whose square is -1.

subsection.p: The square root of any negative number can be written as the product of a real number and i. For example, \sqrt{-4}\amp=\sqrt{-1\cdot 4} \amp= \sqrt{-1}\sqrt{4}=i\cdot2 or \sqrt{-4}=2i. Any number that is the product of i and a real number is called an imaginary number.

note.p: Every negative real number has two imaginary square roots, i\sqrt{a} and -i\sqrt{a}, because \left(i\sqrt{a}\right)^2=i^2(\sqrt{a})^2=-a and \left(-i\sqrt{a}\right)^2=(-i)^2(\sqrt{a})^2=-a For example, the two square roots of -9 are 3i and -3i.

subsection.title: Complex Numbers
subsection.p: Consider the quadratic equation x^2 - 2x + 5 = 0 Using the quadratic formula to solve the equation, we find x=\frac{-(-2)\pm\sqrt{(-2)^2-4(1)(5)}}{2}=\frac{2\pm\sqrt{-16}}{2} If we now replace \sqrt{-16} with 4i, we have x=\frac{2\pm4i}{2}=1\pm2i The two solutions are 1 + 2i and 1 - 2i. These numbers are examples of complex numberscomplex number.

assemblage.title: Complex Numbers
assemblage.p: A complex numbercomplex number can be written in the form a+bi, where a and b are real numbers.

subsection.p: Here are some examples of complex numbers. 3-5i\text{, }~~~2+\sqrt{7}i\text{, }~~~\frac{4-i}{3}\text{, }~~~6i\text{, }~~~\text{ and } -9 In a complex number a+bi, a is called the real partreal part, and b is called the imaginary partimaginary part. All real numbers are also complex numbers (with the imaginary part equal to zero). A complex number whose real part equals zero is called a pure imaginarypure imaginary number.

statement.p: Write the solutions to , \dfrac{2\pm\sqrt{-4}}{2}, as complex numbers.

solution.p: Because \sqrt{-4}=\sqrt{-1}\sqrt{4}=2i, we have \dfrac{2\pm\sqrt{-4}}{2}=\dfrac{2\pm2i}{2}, or 1\pm i. The solutions are 1+i and 1-i.

subsection.p: All the properties of real numbers listed in Algebra Skills Refresher are also true of complex numbers. We can carry out arithmetic operations with complex numbers.

subsection.title: Products of Complex Numbers
subsection.p: To find the product of two imaginary numbers, we use the fact that i^2=-1. For example, (3i )\cdot(4i ) \amp= 3\cdot4 i^2 \amp= 12(-1) = -12 To find the product of two complex numbers, we use the FOIL method, as if the numbers were binomials. For example, (2 + 3i )(3 - 5i ) = 6 - 10i + 9i - 15i^2 Because i^2=-1, the last term, -15i^2, can be replaced by -15(-1), or 15, to obtain 6 - 10i + 9i + 15 Finally, we combine the real parts and imaginary parts to obtain (6 + 15) + (-10i + 9i ) = 21 - i

solution.p: We multiply numerator and denominator by \alert{i}. \frac{10-15i}{5i}\amp=\frac{(10-15i)\cdot \alert{i}}{5i\cdot \alert{i}}\amp\amp \amp=\frac{10i-15i^2}{5i^2}\amp\amp \blert{\text{Replace }i^2 \text{ by } -1.} \amp=\frac{10i+15}{-5}\amp\amp \amp=\frac{10i}{-5}+\frac{15}{-5}\amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide }-5 \text{ into each term of numerator.}} \amp=-2i-3 The quotient is -3 - 2i.

If the divisor has both a real and an imaginary part, we multiply numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator.

subsection.title: Zeros of Polynomials
subsection.p: Because we can add, subtract, and multiply any two complex numbers, we can use a complex number as an input for a polynomial function. Thus, we can extend the domain of any polynomial to include all complex numbers.

statement.p: Evaluate the polynomial f(x) = x^2 - 2x + 2 for x = 1 + i, then simplify.

solution.p: We substitute x = \alert{1 + i} to find f(\alert{1 + i} ) \amp = (\alert{1 + i} )^2 - 2(\alert{1 + i} ) + 2 \amp = 1^2 + 2i + i^2 - 2 - 2i + 2 \amp = 1 + 2i + (-1) - 2 - 2i + 2 \amp =0 Thus, f(1 + i ) = 0, so 1 + i is a solution of x^2 - 2x + 2 = 0.

subsection.p: In , we learned that irrational solutions of quadratic equations occur in conjugate pairs, x=\frac{-b}{2a}+\frac{\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} ~~\text{ and }~~ x=\frac{-b}{2a}-\frac{\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} If the discriminant D = b^2 - 4ac is negative, the two solutions are complex conjugates, z=\frac{-b}{2a}+\frac{i\sqrt{\abs{D}}}{2a} ~~\text{ and }~~ \overline{z}=\frac{-b}{2a}-\frac{i\sqrt{\abs{D}}}{2a} Thus, if we know that z is a complex solution of a quadratic equation, we know that \overline{z} is the other solution. The quadratic equation with solutions z and \overline{z} is (x - z)(x - \overline{z}) \amp = 0 x^2-(z+ \overline{z}) +z\overline{z}\amp = 0

ol.li: Find a quadratic equation with one solution being z = 7 - 5i.

li.p: The conjugate of z = 7 - 5i is \overline{z} = 7 + 5i, so z\overline{z} \amp= (7 - 5i )(7 + 5i ) \amp= 49 - 25i^2 \amp= 49 + 25 \amp= 74

The other solution of the equation is \overline{z} = 7 + 5i, and the equation is (x-z)(x-\overline{z}) = 0. We expand the product to find (x - z)(x - \overline{z}) \amp = x^2 - (z + \overline{z})x + z\overline{z} \amp = x^2 - (7 - 5i + 7 + 5i )x + 74 \amp = x^2 - 14x + 74 The equation is x^2 - 14x + 74 = 0.

subsection.p: One of the most important results in mathematics is the fundamental theorem of algebrafundamental theorem of algebra, which says that if we allow complex numbers as inputs, then every polynomial p(x) of degree n\ge 1 has exactly n complex number zeros.

sidebyside.p: As a result, the factor theorem tells that every polynomial of degree n can be factored as the product of n linear terms. For example, although the graph of y = x^4 + 4 shown at right has no x-intercepts, the fundamental theorem tells us that there are four complex solutions to x^4 + 4 = 0, and that x^4 + 4 can be factored.

subsection.p: You can check that the four solutions to x^4 + 4 = 0 are 1 + i, -1 + i, -1 - i , and 1 - i. For example, if x = 1 + i, then x^2 = (1 + i )^2 = 1 + 2i + i^2 = 2i and x^4 = \left(x^2\right)^2 = (2i )^2 = -4, so x^4+4=(-4)+4=0.

Because each zero corresponds to a factor of the polynomial, the factored form of x^4 + 4 is x^4 + 4 = \left[x - (1 + i )\right]\left[x - (-1 + i )\right]\left[x - (-1 - i )\right]\left[x - (1 - i )\right]

note.p: The four solutions to x^4 + 4 = 0 form two complex conjugate pairs, namely 1\pm i and -1\pm i. In fact, for every polynomial with real coefficients, the nonreal zeros always occur in complex conjugate pairs.

solution.p: The other two zeros are -3i and 2 - i. The factored form of the polynomial is (x - 3i )(x + 3i )[x - (2 + i )][x - (2 - i )] We multiply together the factors to find the polynomial. The product of (x - 3i )(x + 3i ) is x^2 + 9, and [x - (2 + i )][x - (2 - i )] \amp = x^2 - (2 + i + 2 - i )x + (2 + i )(2 - i ) \amp = x^2 - 4x + 5 Finally, we multiply these two partial products to find the polynomial we seek, (x^2 + 9)(x^2 - 4x + 5) = x^4 - 4x^3 + 14x^2 - 36x + 45

subsection.title: Graphing Complex Numbers
subsection.p: Real numbers can be plotted on a number line, but to graph a complex number we use a plane, called the complex plane. In the complex planecomplex plane, the real numbers lie on the horizontal or real axisreal axis, and pure imaginary numbers lie on the vertical or imaginary axisimaginary axis.

sidebyside.p: To plot a complex number a + bi, we move a units from the origin in the horizontal direction and b units in the vertical direction. The numbers 2 + 3i and 2 - 3i are plotted at left.
